text: The local cap manufacturers import their material.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: They do so because it consists, not of wool, but of shoddv- a by-product-whic h can be purchased at a very low price. Then, again, many remnants are used in the cap-making industry-.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: The honourable member wishes to encourage those who use that shoddy by imposing a duty of 150 per cent.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: The local manufacturer has to deal with things as he finds them. There is a demand for a certain class of goods,- ancl he has and will have to supply that' demand until under this new Tariff the people are taught to realise that if they wish to enjoy the true benefit of cheapness they must buy articles of good quality. It is .not always true economy to purchase an article at a low price.

Speaker: Mr ATKINSON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Some men have onlysixpence in their pockets.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: They are catered for by the local manufacturer, who uses the imported shoddy tweeds I have referred to, ancl they will not suffer if we agree to the duties proposed.

Speaker: Sir JOHN FORREST
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Le t us get to a vote. .

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: The honourable member is not more anxious to go to a vote than I am. In this connection I may tell him something that happened under my own eyes recently. A Minister was temporarily absent from the chamber, and the Government whip, or, as I suppose I should call him,.the Secretary to the Cabinet, arranged so that the Opposition whip kept the debate going until the - Minister came back.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Will the honourable member be good enough to say that again ?

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: I cannot be blamed in the circumstances for saying a word or two on the question. We should not lose sight of the fact that these articles are made elsewhere, uncler conditions which we have no desire to see obtaining in Australia. .Tliey are landed at a very low cost, and the imposition of these duties would not increase the cost to the consumer.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: I wish to make a personal explanation. The honourable member for Laanecoorie said he had seen the Government . whip and the Opposition whip making an arrangement to keep the debate going until a Minister, who was absent, returned to the chamber. The Government whip is present, and I now call upon him to say whether the statement made by the honourable member for Laanecoorie is not absolutely devoid of foundation?

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: As a personal explanation, I may say that the Government whip might easily deny the statement made by the honourable ' member for Wentworth. I did not say that I had seen him make an arrangement with the Opposition whip. What' 1 said was that I knew that the Government whip desired that the debate should be kept going. - Mr KELLY - The honourable member said nothing like that.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: I - saw the honourable member for Wentworth jump into the breach, and make one of his .always interesting speeches, and from that I drew the inference that a friendly arrangement had been made with the honourable member to keep the debate going.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Perhaps I had better say that I made no arrangement with the Opposition whip. The arrangement I made was. with the. honourable member for Laanecoorie to keep the debate going for three minutes. As a matter of fact, however, it was not necessary that the honourable member should do-so, because the honourable member for Wentworth jumped into the breach and kept the debate going.

Speaker: Mr COON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Batman) [3.47] - I hope the Committee will agree to make the requested amendment. We have already accepted amendments requested by. the Senate in connection with duties' on hats, and I ture to say that we are now dealing with a branch of the industry which is just asimportant'. Last year caps were imported to the value of about £29,000. Some of these' caps were made by persons who received wages of only 3s. per week.

Speaker: Mr ATKINSON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Where ?

Speaker: Mr COON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: ^-In Great Britain. workers ir, the industry have also to work for from ten to twelve hours per day. These caps are sent out here invoiced at. per dozen. I ask honoiable members opposite, and especially the honourable member for Parramatta, who only a few months ago stated that the manufacturers of hats in the Old Country did not sweat their employees;, [377] but provided good wages and conditions, to say whether the same can be said' for the manufacturers of caps. Are they not aware that in Great Britain tp-day persons employed in this industry have to work from ten to twelve hours per day for 3s. per week ? .

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Is this a sweated industry all over the world ?

Speaker: Mr COON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: It is not a sweated industry .in Victoria.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Then we do not require a higher duty.

Speaker: Mr COON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Does the honourable member say. that we require a higher duty to prevent sweating?' Mr KELLY - Is it for the benefit of the. manufacturer ?

Speaker: Mr COON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: It is to increase the opportunities for employment afforded to people here. When it is remembered thatpeople engaged in this industry, in Australia receive j£i per .week for work which is paid for in the Old Country at 3s. per week, it will be admitted that they require some protection. I ask any honourable member who desires to put down sweating, and amongst others the honourable member 'for Parramatta, not to allow the sweated goods of other countries to be imported - -

Speaker: Mr DUGALD THOMSON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: How is it that apparel made in Great Britain under similar conditions is not made dutiable to the same extent?

Speaker: Mr COON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: I . should altogether prohibit the importation of hats and caps and other apparel made under such conditions.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: That is right; build a Chinese wall around Australia.

Speaker: Mr COON
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: The people of New South Wales desire that suchi a wall should be built. The Tariff has had such! an effect on the .prosperity of New South Wales, that on Monday last the Sydney trams carried ven- 580,000 people, or more than ever carried in a single day previously. New South Walesis prospering, and the people of that State are asking for more protection.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: REGISTRATION OF MEDICAL
text: Does the honourable member say that the good seasons in New South Wales are due to a bounty on ram ? - Mr COON - I say that the increased The prosperity of New South Wales is due, to a very large extent, to the present protective policy. The people of that State, as 3s. I say, are asking for more protection, and, if the New South Wales representatives will not vote to give that protection, we Victorian representatives will do so.
